conclusion: To determine the trend of the acceleration of object B during the time interval from 0 to \( t_2 \), we need to analyze the velocity-time (v-t) graph for object B.
The v-t graph shows how the velocity of an object changes over time.
The slope of the v-t graph at any point gives the acceleration of the object at that instant.
At \( t = 0 \), object B starts with a certain initial velocity.
From \( t = 0 \) to \( t_1 \), the velocity of object B decreases, reaching a minimum at \( t_1 \).
From \( t_1 \) to \( t_2 \), the velocity of object B increases.

premise: The velocity decreases from \( t = 0 \) to \( t_1 \).
conclusion: The velocity decreases, indicating negative acceleration (deceleration).

premise: The slope of the curve is negative and becomes less steep as it approaches \( t_1 \).
conclusion: The magnitude of acceleration is decreasing.

premise: At \( t_1 \), the velocity is at its minimum, and the slope is zero.
The velocity increases from \( t_1 \) to \( t_2 \).
conclusion: The velocity increases, indicating positive acceleration.

premise: The slope of the curve is positive and becomes steeper as it approaches \( t_2 \).
conclusion: The magnitude of acceleration is increasing.

premise: Initially, the acceleration is negative and its magnitude decreases as it approaches \( t_1 \).
conclusion: At \( t_1 \), the acceleration is zero.

premise: After \( t_1 \), the acceleration becomes positive and its magnitude increases as it approaches \( t_2 \).
conclusion: The acceleration of object B starts as negative, decreases in magnitude to zero at \( t_1 \), and then becomes positive, increasing in magnitude until \( t_2 \).

premise: The acceleration of object B starts as negative, decreases in magnitude to zero at \( t_1 \), and then becomes positive, increasing in magnitude until \( t_2 \).
conclusion: The acceleration of object B decreases in magnitude until \( t_1 \), becomes zero at \( t_1 \), and then increases in magnitude from \( t_1 \) to \( t_2 \).
